sentences: Joseph "Joe" McElderry (; born 16 June 1991)
section: N/A

sentences: is an English singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: He won the sixth series of the ITV show The X Factor in 2009.
section: N/A

sentences: His first single "The Climb" reached number one   on both the UK Singles Chart and the  Irish Singles Charts.

sentences: He was also the winner of the second series of Popstar to Operastar in 2011 and the first series of The Jump in 2014.

section: N/A

sentences: To date, McElderry has released five top 20 albums – two of them reaching the UK top three.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Born in South Shields, England, McElderry is the only child of Jim and Eileen (née Joyce) McElderry.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The couple separated when McElderry was a child.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He was raised in a small flat in South Shields.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: McElderry attended Harton Technology College in Lisle Road, South Shields, before joining South Tyneside College to study AS level school qualifications.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Subsequently, he joined Newcastle College to study performing arts.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He was the Pride of South Tyneside's Young Performer of the Year in 2008.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He studied for BTEC National Diploma in Performing Arts (Advanced Performance) at Newcastle College Performance Academy.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 2009, he took the role of 'Danny Zuko' in Grease which was performed at Harton Technology College.

sentences: McElderry auditioned for The X Factor in 2007 and made it to bootcamp.

sentences: At the time, he believed that he was too young compared to the other contestants and opted to walk away.

sentences: He auditioned again in 2009 and sang Luther Vandross's "Dance with My Father".
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: Mentored by Cheryl Cole, he made it through to the live finals and was announced the winner on 13 December 2009, beating runner up Olly Murs with his version of "The Climb".

sentences: McElderry's prize, as winner, was a recording contract with Simon Cowell's Syco record label, whose parent company is Sony Music Entertainment.
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: The contract had a stated value of £1 million, of which £150,000 was a cash advance and the remainder allocated to recording and marketing costs.
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: Along with The X Factor finalists, McElderry recorded vocal for featured on a charity single, a cover of Michael Jackson's hit "You Are Not Alone".
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: It was released in aid of London's Great Ormond Street Hospital.
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: The finalists premiered the song live on the edition of 15 November of the programme; the single was available for digital download that day and a physical release followed the day after.
section: == Career == | ==== The X Factor ====

sentences: The single reached number one in the UK Singles Chart.

== Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: After The X Factor ====
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry's debut single, "The Climb", was available to download at midnight on 14 December 2009 and was released physically on 16 December 2009.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: According to industry sources, approximately 100,000 copies of the single were sold on the day of its release but it was not enough to knock Rage Against The Machine off the spot in the UK in its opening week.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: On 18 December 2009, it was announced that McElderry secured the top spot in the Irish Singles Chart for 11–17 December 2009."The Climb" was a contender for 2009's UK Christmas number one, competing against, and losing to, Rage Against the Machine's "Killing in the Name".
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry's single sold 450,000 compared to Rage Against the Machine's 502,000 after a Facebook-based campaign was started in protest of The X Factor's dominance of the Christmas number one title.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: This was the first time since 2004 that the X Factor winning single was denied the top spot for Christmas in the UK Singles Charts.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: Simon Cowell stated that he was "gutted for Joe because a number one single meant a lot to him.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: But I have to congratulate Jon and Tracy [Morter, who started the Facebook campaign]."
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry's single stayed at number one on the Irish charts for a second week securing him the Irish Christmas number one (18–25 December 2009), and the song moved up to the top spot in the UK Singles Chart on 27 December.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: The single had the fifth highest sales of all UK singles released in 2009 staying one week at No. 1, and was the top-selling Irish single of 2009, where it remained at the top spot for four consecutive weeks.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: "The Climb" was nominated in the British Single category at the 2010 BRIT Awards but lost out to fellow X Factor contestants JLS.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry performed "Don't Stop Believin'" and presented an award at the 15th National Television Awards in London on 20 January 2010.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: In January 2010, he participated in the Helping Haiti charity single, a cover of "Everybody Hurts" arranged by Simon Cowell in order to raise money for victims of the 2010 Haiti earthquake.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry and seven other finalists, Olly Murs, Stacey Solomon, Danyl Johnson, Lloyd Daniels, John & Edward, Jamie Archer and Lucie Jones, appeared in the X Factor Live tour, which began on 15 February 2010 at the Echo Arena Liverpool and concluded on 4 April at the SECC.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: McElderry performed the songs "Don't Let the Sun Go Down on Me", "Love Story", "Sorry Seems to Be the Hardest Word", "She's Out of My Life", "Don't Stop Believin'" and his debut single "The Climb" on the tour.
section: == Career == | ==== After The X Factor ====

sentences: On 15 March, it was reported that McElderry had signed a modelling deal with Next Models.
